title: If I ask a singer to sing my lyrics, do I have to pay for the recording copyright? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: In the music business, monetary disbursements are the quickest way to “grease the skids” and make things happen. If you *really wanna create something* then come up with a budget of about $2500/song; that will cover hiring real professionals that can compose and produce your ideas for you and you’ll end up with a CD eventually. Having a “concept” of melody that you base your lyrics around makes it easier but it’s not necessary. Neil Peart wrote all the lyrics for the band Rush while Geddy Lee & Alex Lifeson (bassist/guitarist) crafted the tonal arrangements, if I recall correctly. Doing things “on the cheap” will require you to “start a band” and find musicians who want to donate their time to collaborate on musical ideas. This route is often the most painful, as you’ll rarely find quality players who can/wish to donate a couple of nights a week to ultimately what becomes “your art”. Sometimes “lightning strikes” and you meet someone with whom your lyrical abilities pair well with and you become a team. The next step is to create an arrangement and hire session musicians to play on your songs and produce a work of art. The more prepared you are musically (melody & harmony, rhythms, tempos and arrangements) and lyrically going into a recording studio the better. If your “end game” is to make money off your songwriting abilities, then you need to have something out there that piques peoples’ interest; a curation of your creations that is otherwise known as a CD. However… it’s perfectly OK to do things piecemeal and create one tune, put it on a streaming service for others to listen to and then you can start building a fanbase organically. There’s a great book called “How To Make It In The New Music Business” by Ari Herstand that breaks down a lot of “how things work now”. The “oldschool” music business is a dying dinosaur due to streaming services and the like. Organic fans are the best fans because you tend to get to know them personally and they can say “I knew [your name] back when they were just getting started”. There’s a LOT of “unknowns” who have made millions on songwriting and continue to do so. Publishing is the “big money” in the music business, such as getting your tune into a movie or commercial. It’s just knowing to whom and where to sell them. Art is hard. Otherwise everyone would be doing it… actually everyone IS doing it so the “end game” should always be “do it for the love. If you make any money then consider yourself lucky.” ~13

If you want the copyright to be registered, someone’s going to have to pay the registration fee. You could negotiate the contract so that the singer is the one who has to pay it, but if you do so, the singer is likely to up their price by the cost of the registration. It makes more sense to do it yourself. In the US, at least, registering a copyright is not at all difficult, and can be done via the Copyright Office’s web site.
